I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  During the November 2006 country program meeting, the Government of the People’s 
Republic of China (PRC) requested technical assistance (TA) from the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) to develop biomass power generation in rural areas.1 The concept paper was 
approved on 23 February 2007, and a reconnaissance mission was fielded from 11 to 17 March 
2007. The fact-finding mission occurred from 6 to 11 August 2007, during which an agreement 
was  reached  with  the  Government  on  the  TA’s  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  implementation 
arrangements, and financing plan. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Over the past two decades, PRC has achieved an impressive economic growth rate 
averaging over 9.5%. PRC now accounts for 15% of the global economy, up from 3% in 1980. 
Its economy is expected to double from its 2000 level by 2010 and to quadruple by 2020. Given 
this projected growth, the demand for energy—in particular electricity—is expected to continue 
increasing  rapidly.  Per  capita  electricity  consumption  has  risen  dramatically,  from  340  
kilowatt-hours (kWh) in 1983 to 1,840 kWh in 2005. Currently, PRC has the second-largest 
energy demand in the world and will have the largest by 2011. By 2030, it is estimated that PRC 
will account for 20% of global energy demand.2 
 
3.  Such  growth  in  power  generation  capacity  is  unprecedented.  In  PRC,  installed 
generation capacity has increased at an annual average of more than 8% over the past two 
decades. Since 2000, the annual growth of electricity consumption has been about 13%. In 
2006 alone, 105 gigawatts (GW) of new capacity were installed, equivalent to the entire installed 
capacity  in  Africa—and  a  record  annual  increase  for  any  country.  The  rapid  addition  of 
generation capacity has still not fully met PRC’s surging electricity demand; since 2002, more 
than  half  the  provinces  had  to  curtail  power  supplies  during  summer  peak  periods.  PRC 
electricity consumption increased from 259 terawatt-hours (TWh) in 1980 to 2,500 TWh in 2006 
and is projected to increase to 7,230 TWh by 2030 (footnote 2). 
 
4.  Approximately  69%  of  PRC’s  primary  energy  demand  and  82%  of  its  electricity  is 
derived from coal. The country has the third largest proven coal reserves in the world, and it is 
the world’s largest coal producer and consumer, with coal production accounting for 38% of 
global production in 2005, which is projected to increase to 49% by 2030. Coal demand has 
increased from 446 million tons of coal equivalent (mtce) in 1980 to 1,563 mtce in 2005 and is 
projected to increase to 3,462 mtce by 2030. However, coal-fired power generation, using 
conventional  power  generation  technology,  results  in  considerable  environmental  issues.  It 
accounts for about 50% of the country’s sulfur dioxide (SO ) emissions, 80% of nitrogen oxides 
2
(NO ) emissions, and 26% of carbon dioxide (CO ) emissions. Acid rain, caused primarily by 
x 2
SO  and NO  falls on one third of the country and is estimated to cause $4 billion in crop 
2 x
damage and $900 million in material damage annually.3 Approximately 48% of cities fail to meet 
national air quality standards,4 and PRC is projected to become the world’s largest producer of 
the greenhouse gas CO  in 2007. The country is currently responsible for 5.1% of global carbon 
2
emissions, estimated to increase to 28% by 2030.

5.  Traditionally, PRC has been relatively self-sufficient in energy. However, rapid increase 
in internal demand has amplified reliance on imported energy, impacting energy security. The 
country is anticipated to become a net importer of coal in 2007, with imports increasing to 132 
mtce by 2015, representing 10% of the world’s coal trade. Declining domestic oil reserves will 
result in surging imports, from 3.5 million barrels per day in 2006 to an estimated 13.1 million 
barrels per day in 2030. Imported oil is projected to increase from 49% of primary oil demand in 
2005 to 65% in 2015, rising to 79% by 2030. PRC will become the world’s second largest oil 
importer around 2010, and by 2030 will import the equivalent amount of the 27 European Union 
member states combined. PRC is currently relatively self-sufficient in natural gas; however by 
2015, it will import about 22% of its supply, which will rise to 54% by 2030 (footnote 2). 
 
6.  Biomass, mainly crop residue in rural areas, is an underutilized energy resource that is 
mostly  burned  in  the  fields,  causing  the  following  environmental  impacts:  (i)  significantly 
elevated air pollution, including CO , SO , and particulate matter, which impacts public health; 
2 2
(ii) reduced visibility that affects air transportation; and (iii) reduced soil fertility. Alternatively, 
when  waste  crop  residue  is  stockpiled  and  allowed  to  decompose,  it  leads  to  increased 
methane emissions, a potent greenhouse gas. In addition, development of biomass-fired power 
plants5 has several environmental and social benefits, including: (i) reduced air pollution when 
used as a substitute for coal-fired electricity, as biomass combustion results in almost no SO  and 
2
lower particulate matter amounts; (ii) lowered air pollution by ceasing the burning of crop residue; 
and (iii) reduced water pollution, including nitrogen and phosphorous, from decomposing crop 
residue, which can lead to eutrophication of waterways. Further, power is produced with no net 
greenhouse gas emissions because the crops already absorbed the CO  during photosynthesis 
2
prior to harvest. In the context of rural poverty, the conversion of crop residue to power will also 
have significant poverty alleviation benefits as households will have an additional income stream.  
 
7.  While biomass power generation is relatively mature in many developed countries and 
some areas of Asia, it is relatively new to PRC. By 2006, only two straw-fired demonstration 
power plants had begun operation, but the biomass power generation sector is anticipated to 
grow rapidly with a further 38 projects approved in 2006, with a combined capacity of 1.28 GW. 
However, there are several barriers to further its development, including (i) lack of provincial-
level strategic resource optimization planning, (ii) limited availability of project financing due to 
domestic banks’ unfamiliarity with the sector’s risks, (iii) lack of methodologies for resource 
assessment,  (iv)  logistics  issues  such  as  transportation  and  feedstock  storage,  and 
(v) fragmentation of the industry leading to poor coordination and repetition of mistakes. In 2005, 
the State Grid Corporation of China established the National Bio Energy Company, Ltd. (NBE) 
to develop the biomass power generation sector in PRC. NBE, which also has a significant 
research and development program, is currently the largest developer of the sector in PRC 
through its demonstration project in Shandong. There is significant potential for the sector in 
several other provinces, such as the northeastern province of Heilongjiang, which has a high 
availability of biomass and relatively large farms, simplifying the procurement and logistics of 
feedstock supply.  
 
8.  Biomass  power  generation  promotion  is  closely  aligned  with  current  government 
strategies. The Government identified renewable energy development as a strategic priority 
under the 11th Five-Year Plan (11FYP). The 11FYP specifically targets 5.5 GW of biomass 
                                                 
5  Biomass power generation is defined as direct combustion of biomass in a dedicated boiler to produce steam that 
is then used for generating electricity/heat, i.e., hot water for heating homes and buildings. It does not include  
co-firing of biomass in coal-fired power plants, municipal solid waste to energy plants, or installation of biomass 
fired boilers within an existing industrial facility for utilizing industry-specific waste.

3
power  generation  capacity  by  2010,  increasing  to  30  GW  by  2020.6 The  development  of 
renewable energy sources, including biomass power generation, is also prioritized by the 2007 
National Climate Change Strategy, 2005 Medium- and Long-Term Energy Conservation Plan, 
and 2007 11th Five-Year Plan for Energy Development. The 2007 Medium- and Long-Term 
Development Plan for Renewable Energy targets 15% electricity generation from renewable 
energy sources by 2020. The 2006 Renewable Energy Law was enacted to provide regulatory 
support  for  renewable  energy  development,  and  subsequent  regulations  have  allowed  a 
preferential tariff for biomass projects, e.g., an additional CNY0.25 per kWh over coal-based 
power. Additionally, biomass power generation utilizes waste, thereby directly supporting other 
11FYP  priorities  of  resource  conservation  and  waste  product  recycling.  Development  of 
indigenous power supplies also improves national energy security, and additional farm earnings 
from the sale of agricultural waste will also increase rural incomes.    
 
9.  Support  for  biomass  power  generation  development  is  consistent  with  ADB’s  
medium-term strategy II for 2006–2008 and the PRC country strategy and program.7 ADB has 
been actively supporting bioenergy development in PRC, including Loan 1924-PRC: Efficient 
Utilization of Agricultural Wastes, which involved rural biomass resource utilization, and TA 
4810-PRC: Preparing National Strategy for Rural Biomass Renewable Energy Development. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The impact of the TA will be the improvement of environmental conditions in rural areas, 
and the outcome will be increased biomass power generation in the province of Heilongjiang.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
11.  The TA will include the following activities: 
 
  1.   Biomass Power Generation in PRC: Barriers and Lessons Learned  
 
12.  Component 1 will assess the barriers to and lessons learned during the implementation 
of initial pilot biomass power plants in PRC. The analysis will include assessment of relevant 
equipment technology, feedstock collection and transportation management, feedstock pricing 
structures  and  levels,  financing  barriers,  and  environmental  and  social  implications  from 
biomass  power  generation  projects.  The  lessons  learned  will  be  documented,  and 
recommendations will be provided for overcoming barriers to project expansion. Where suitable, 
international experience will be incorporated. Provincial governments and project developers will 
use the report in planning biomass power generation development. The report may also be 
suitable for national policymakers. The report will be widely disseminated and publicly released 
in a series of workshops and a technical conference.

7  ADB. 2006. People’s Republic of China: Country Strategy and Program Update (2007-2008). Manila.

4   
2.   Biomass Power Plant Technical Studies 
 
13.  Component 2 will include specific technical studies to address key barriers to future 
sustainable  development  of  biomass  power  generation  in  PRC.  These  will  include  (i)  an 
assessment of cellulosic ethanol technology report, and (ii) a commodity market analysis report 
on biomass power generation feedstock.  
 
3.  Provincial Biomass Power Generation Strategy  
 
14.  Component 3 will prepare a biomass power generation strategy for the province of 
Heilongjiang to optimize biomass power utilization. Robust provincial-level planning will become 
increasingly important as the biomass energy market develops in order to maximize resource 
utilization,  ensure  adequate  feedstock  availability  for  proposed  investments,  and  prevent 
unsustainable development. This component will include a biomass resource assessment for 
Heilongjiang, suitable for replication in other provinces, and preparation of a biomass power 
generation development strategy for Heilongjiang.  
 
4.  Capacity Building and TA Output Dissemination 
 
15.  Component 4 will include capacity-building and dissemination activities, including (i) 
workshops  for  financial  institutions  and  provincial  government  officials  to  increase  their 
awareness of biomass power generation benefits, and (ii) dissemination of TA outputs through 
relevant channels, including a biomass power generation conference.  
 
16.  The main deliverables from the TA will be (i) report analyzing the barriers to biomass 
power generation development and lessons learned from existing projects, (ii) two technical 
study  reports,  (iii)  provincial-level  biomass  survey,  (iv)  provincial-level  biomass  power 
generation  development  strategy,  (v)  dissemination  workshops  for  financial  institutions  and 
provincial government officials, and (vi) biomass power generation conference.    
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
17.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $800,000, of which $600,000 will be financed on 
a grant basis by Second Danish Cooperation Fund for Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency 
in Rural Areas to be administered by ADB. The Government will fund the remaining $200,000 
by providing office accommodation, support facilities, and staff salaries. Details of the cost 
estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
18.  The TA will be implemented over a 1-year period from January 2008 to January 2009. 
NBE will be the Executing Agency (EA) for the project and will also implement components 1, 2, 
and 4. The Implementing Agency (IA) for component 3 will be the Heilongjiang Provincial 
Development and Reform Commission. Counterpart financing will be $100,000 from NBE and 
$100,000 from the Heilongjiang Provincial Development and Reform Commission. A steering 
committee will be formed to oversee TA implementation, and will include representatives from 
industry and government. International and national consultants will be selected and engaged in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to 
time). The consultants’ services will be provided through a consulting firm selected after the 
submission of simplified technical proposals and the use of quality- and cost-based selection 
methods (quality/cost ratio: 80/20).

5
 
19.  The estimated allocation of consulting services will be five international consultants 
(combined 9.5 person-months), and eight national consultants (combined 38 person-months). 
The international consultants will include (i) biomass power generation expert, (ii) biomass 
power generation financial specialist, (iii) cellulosic ethanol specialist, (iv) biomass feedstock 
market analyst, and (v) biomass resource assessment specialist. The national consultants will 
include (i) biomass power generation specialist, (ii) financial analyst, (iii) safeguard specialist 
(environment/social), (iv) cellulosic ethanol specialist, (v) biomass feedstock market analyst, (vi) 
biomass resource specialist, (vii) renewable energy planner, and (viii) administrative assistant. 
Outline terms of reference for the consulting services are provided in Appendix 3. Equipment 
may be financed under the TA and be procured by the international consultants in accordance 
with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). This equipment will 
be handed over to the IA upon TA completion. The EA, with inputs from the consultants, will 
finalize the scope and content of the training and information dissemination programs. Financial 
arrangements for the trainings, seminars, conferences, and surveys will be included in the 
consulting firm’s contract. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 to the Government 
of the People’s Republic of China to be financed on a grant basis by the Second Danish 
Cooperation Fund for Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency in Rural Areas for Development 
of Biomass Power Generation in Rural Areas, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants 
 
1.  Biomass Power Generation Expert (4 person-months). The consultant will undertake 
the following activities:  
  
(i)  act as an overall team leader for the technical assistance (TA) project;  
(ii)  coordinate consultants to ensure that implementation and reporting is on schedule; 
(iii)  liaison closely with the Executing Agency (EA), relevant government officials, Asian 
Development Bank (ADB), and consultants;  
(iv)  act as the technical lead responsible for component 1’s implementation;  
(v)  conduct site visits to at least 3 operational biomass power plants to assess lessons 
learned and implementation barriers; 
(vi)  consult  with  stakeholders,  e.g.,  academia,  government  officials,  developers, 
financiers, and feedstock suppliers, to assess biomass power generation barriers 
and lessons learned from existing projects; 
(vii)  assess biomass power generation implementation barriers and lessons learned for 
the People’s Republic of China (PRC), including (a) the historical context of biomass 
power generation development in PRC, the regulatory and policy framework for this 
development, and the summary of reference studies completed to date, (b) process 
management and technology, including assessment of feedstock supply risks and 
development of risk mitigation measures for them; analysis of feedstock collection 
mechanisms, including broker certification and purchase contract systems; logistical 
analysis  of  transportation  systems,  including  assessment  of  feedstock  handling 
efficiencies and feedstock pre-treatment such as shredding and bailing; analysis of 
methods to reduce feedstock loss during transportation and storage; assessment of 
impact on alternative feedstock use; and baling and pelletization technologies, (c) 
commodity  pricing,  including  feedstock  commodity  market  analysis,  (d)  project 
financing  barriers,  including  assessment  of  barriers  to  financing  biomass  power 
generation  projects  and  assessment  of  carbon  financing  benefits,  and  (e) 
environmental  and  social  benefits,  including  quantification  of  the  environmental 
benefits  available  from  biomass  projects  through  operational  assessment  of  the 
demonstration projects, and analysis of income benefits to farmers and development 
of methods to maximize social benefits. 
(viii)  provide  specific  recommendations  for  overcoming  barriers  to  biomass  power 
generation  sector  development,  including  required  policy  and  regulatory 
developments, and incorporate international experience; 
(ix)  undertake a cost benefit analysis for biomass power plant development; 
(x)  coordinate the biomass power generation steering committee; 
(xi)  develop recommendations for future industry coordination; 
(xii)  receive  and  respond  to  media  requests  for  project  information  as  required  and 
approved by ADB and the EA;  
(xiii)  act as a resource speaker for the biomass conference; and  
(xiv)  work closely with the EA to design the consultation workshops.  
 
2.  Biomass Power Generation Financial Specialist (1 person-month). The consultant 
will undertake the following activities for component 1: 
 
(i)  assess barriers to financing biomass power generation projects;  
(ii)  analyze financial risks and lessons learned from the pilot biomass power plants;

(v)  assess feedstock pricing fluctuations from pilot biomass power generation projects; 
(vi)  assess major pricing risks for typical localized biomass feedstock markets, including 
(a) supply contract risks, (b) transportation and storage risks, (c) pricing risks, (d) 
competitive use risks, and (e) regulatory and policy risks; 
(vii)  provide recommendations to address major market risks; 
(viii)  provide short-medium term biomass pricing projections for selected markets; and 
(ix)  develop suitable methodologies for feedstock pricing projections. 
 
11.  Biomass Resource Specialist (6 person-months). The consultant will undertake the 
following activities in support of component 3: 
 
(i)  manage the implementation of the Heilongjiang biomass assessment (2 months); 
(ii)  work  closely  with  the  EA,  the  Implementing  Agency  (IA),  and  the  international 
consultant to design a biomass resource assessment for Heilongjiang, incorporating 
national and international best practices;  
(iii)  obtain several quotes to undertake a resource survey for Heilongjiang;  
(iv)  supervise  the  biomass  resource  survey  contract,  including  management  of 
contractors and technical review of reports;  
(v)  under the supervision of the international biomass resource specialist, assist in the 
development of the biomass power generation development strategy (2 months);  
(vi)  work  closely  with  the  Heilongjiang  provincial  government  to  identify  detailed 
requirements for development of a biomass power generation strategy; and 
(vii)  analyze biomass power generation strategies developed in other provinces, and 
utilize relevant components and approaches if suitable.  
 
12.  Renewable  Energy  Planner  (6  person-months).  The  consultant  will  undertake  the 
following activities in support of component 3:  
 
(i)  manage preparation of the biomass power generation development strategy; 
(ii)  work  closely  with  the  Heilongjiang  provincial  government  to  identify  detailed 
requirements for biomass power generation strategy development;  
(iii)  analyze biomass power generation strategies developed in other provinces, and 
utilize relevant components and approaches if suitable; and  
(iv)  under the supervision of the international biomass resource specialist, prepare the 
biomass power generation development strategy for Heilongjiang.  
 
13.  Administrative  Assistant  (8  person-months).  The  consultant  will  undertake  the 
following activities for components 1, 2, 3, and 4: 
 
(i)  provide administrative and logistical support for national and international consultants, 
e.g., booking of accommodation and airfare and arranging meetings; 
(ii)  provide  verbal  translation  services  during  TA  meetings,  translate  short  written 
documents and working correspondence, e.g., e-mails and short reports, and manage 
translation of larger reports by external contractors; 
(iii)  assist in coordinating site visits and collating data from field teams; 
(iv)  identify and collect relevant background reports, articles, and other data on biomass 
development in PRC, and maintain a database of the collected information; and  
(v)  provide  logistical,  organizational,  and  administrative  support  to  the  EA  for  the 
consultation  workshops  and  biomass  power  generation  conference  including  (a) 
arranging venues, (b) managing correspondence with attendees, (c) assisting in 
determining the workshop/conference design and content, and (d) other items.
